origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Center for Japanese Studies.

did.unittitle: Center for Japanese Studies (University of Michigan) records
did.abstract: Correspondence, reports, budgets, and other materials concerning the establishment of the Okayama Field Station and the subsequent publication of Village Japan, including correspondence with Douglas MacArthur; also records and minutes, 1947-1987, of the executive committee of the Center for Japanese Studies; also papers relating to the programs and financial operations of the center; and photographs and films.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was transferred by the Center for Japanese Studies (donor # 3854) in various accessions from 1961 to 2008.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Board of Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Center for Japanese Studies (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The University of Michigan's Center for Japanese Studies (CJS) was established in 1947, and offered its first classes in the fall semester of 1948. The center was one of many "area studies" facilities established at American universities after the Second World War, but was the first such center in the United States that was truly interdisciplinary. The drive for area studies grew out of a sense among American policy makers that a lack of American expertise in foreign language and culture had hindered the U.S. war effort. Area studies centers were intended to remedy this weakness by encouraging intense interdisciplinary scholarship with a strong focus on the mastery of language. The University of Michigan was a logical choice for a Japanese area studies center: it had an established Japanese Studies program (a part of the Oriental Civilization Program) and had housed the Army's Japanese Language School during the Second World War.

The new center was designed to further the academic study of Japan by promoting research, training specialists, and building a research library. From its very beginning, the center was interdisciplinary, drawing faculty from a variety of departments including Oriental language (now Asian Languages), geography, anthropology, and political science. To supplement its classes in Ann Arbor, the center created a field station in Okayama, Japan, in 1950. Scholars at the station pursued original research while immersed in Japanese culture. Village Japan a study by Richard K. Beardsley, John W. Hall, and Robert E. Ward, was the most notable product of this period. Five years later, the center closed the field station, but it continued to support American scholarship in Japan. The center also promoted international scholarship through conferences and visiting professorships.

Most of the area studies centers created in the immediate post-war period, including CJS, were initiated with large grants from the Carnegie Corporation. In 1958, the federal government increased funding of the area centers with the passage of the National Defense Education Act (NDEA). Title VI of that act specifically promoted area and language studies. In the 1970s, however, government and private foundation funding began to dry up, and the center was forced to look elsewhere for funding.

During the 1970s and 1980s, the center became more reliant on funds from corporations and the Japanese government. The Toyota Visiting Professorship, for instance, was established in 1987 with a grant from the Toyota Motor Corporation. The Toyota Visiting Professorship offered students to attend seminars and lectures, as well as attend classes, with world-renowned scholars.

Adapting to the changing needs of students and faculty in the early 1990s, CJS began an afternoon lecture series, which touched on all areas of Japanese culture, economic, and political history. Supplementing the lecture series, is a vibrant film series. The film and lecture series act together for the promotion and dissemination of research about Japan. CJS' website offers extensive resources for students, teachers, and K-14 materials. Currently, outreach efforts include the Japan Technology Management Program, which challenges traditional uses of science and technology, and the continued support of the Asian Library. The library is now the second largest library of Japanese and other Asian language texts in the country.

chronlist.head: Directors of the Center for Japanese Studies

scopecontent.p: The Center for Japanese Studies records document the founding and functioning of the center, covering the period from the late-1940s through the1990s. The center's executive committee minutes and official correspondence cover most of this period evenly. Otherwise, documentation of the center's history is somewhat uneven. The center's first decade is well covered, with a considerable amount of field research notes and audio-visual material. From the early-1960s on, however, such documentation is sparse. This later period is documented in other ways, though. The records include a considerable amount of material concerning grants and fundraising, and these documents often describe the center's activities in detail. The records pertaining to special activities of the center also cover the later decades well.
The records are arranged in nine series: Administrative Files, Correspondence, Course Material, Faculty Files, Financial, Grants, Research Special Activities, and Audio-Visual Material.

scopecontent.p: The Administrative Files series (1947-1991, 2.5 linear feet) consists of minutes of the center's executive committee meetings, staff meeting notes, and meetings and reports evaluating the center's programs. The executive committee minutes cover a wide variety of topics, including funding, appointments, and research. The staff meeting files often concern future plans for the center.

Early Material on Area Studies and Japanese Studies
Faculty Advisory Committee on International Programs (FACIP)

Inter-University Center for Japanese Language Studies, Annual Meeting, March 8 and 9
Program for Inter-Institutional Collaboration in Area Studies

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (1950-1987, 2 linear feet) consists primarily of a log of the center's official correspondence. The correspondence concerns a wide variety of topics, including funding, appointments, research, and conferences.

did.unittitle: Correspondence re the closing of the Okayama Field Station

scopecontent.p: The Course Material series (1963, 1985-1986, two folders) consists of several syllabi and course descriptions from CJS courses.

did.unittitle: Master of Arts, Japanese Studies, Program Handbook
Nagara, Susumu Japanese Pidgin English in Hawaii: A Bilingual Description. Hawaii: University of Hawaii Press

scopecontent.p: The Faculty Files series (1975-1986, .25 linear feet) consists primarily of papers memorializing distinguished CJS faculty.

The Financial series (1961-1992, 4.5 linear feet) is divided into three subseries: Budget, Area Studies Funding and Fundraising. The Budget subseries consists of correspondence and reports detailing the budget of the center. The Area Studies Funding subseries consists of correspondence and reports concerning the status of funding for area studies programs. The Fundraising subseries consists of correspondence, proposals and reports concerning fundraising for the center.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous Financial Papers and Correspondence; mostly re: budget
Budget Negotiations with College of Literature, Science and the Arts

scopecontent.p: The Grants (1954-1997, 3 linear feet) series is divided into two subseries: grants to the center and grants by the center. The former consists of correspondence, proposals and reports concerning outside grants to the center. It is organized alphabetically by the name of the foundation, corporation or government bureau administering the grant. The latter consists of correspondence, proposals and reports concerning grants from the center to individual faculty members, and grants to outside researchers requesting funds to use the Asia library. It is organized chronologically.

scopecontent.p: The Research series (1950-1979, 1 linear foot) consists of notes and manuscripts relating to research projects, and includes correspondence and other documents relating to the Okayama field research station. Most of the research notes and manuscripts are from the 1950s. The correspondence concerning the field station includes letters from Douglas MacArthur.

did.unittitle: Establishment of Research Center in Japan (Includes Correspondence with Douglas MacArthur)
Okayama Field Station; Policies and Objectives
Visit of Regent Bonisteel and Dean Niehuss to Okayama Field Station
Japanese Journal Articles re: Field Station (in Japanese)
"The Relationship of Cultural Patterns and Personality," Interdisciplinary Research Report Directed by Tsuneo Muramatsu

scopecontent.p: The Special Activities series (1950-1997, 3 linear feet) consists of files concerning a variety of activities that are tangential to the centers primary functions of teaching and researching. The series is arranged alphabetically into 10 subseries: Alumni Material, Conferences, Consultations for Businesses, Faculty Development Seminars, Inter-Collegiate Activities and Organizations, Intra-University Joint Projects, Outreach Programs, Summer Lecture Series, Teachers' Institute in Asian Studies (TIAS), and Visits and Honorary Degrees.

odd.p: (see folder on 1974 visit in Box 5, fundraising series)

scopecontent.p: The Audio-Visual series (1945-1991, 3 linear feet) consists of photographs, negatives, slides, reel-to-reel audio tapes, films, a videotape, and cassette tapes. The material dates from the 1950s through the early 1990s. It primarily consists of material about rural Japan recorded for research purposes, and material documenting the social life and educational activities of the Center for Japanese Studies. Some of the films have been duplicated to U-matic videotape.
